nodes.bodyText: I think this NOT_FOUND response is coming from the containment index, which failed and should have rolled back. Could we have one of the other services fail instead, like the ocfl Index, reference service or membership service? Just to ensure all the transactions are being rolled back.

The Fedora to OCFL mapping is persisted first, and then the containment index. This test does correctly confirm that the OCFL mapping is rolled back when the containment index update fails -- except in MySQL which is apparently not rolling back for some reason.
On GET resource requests, the the OCFL mapping table is accessed when the resource headers are loaded before the containment table is checked.
You can just add the PRIMARY KEY to the fedora_id line, I'm not sure why it disappeared but clearly I made a mistake.

nodes.bodyText:
Yeah, I can change that. I originally wrote it that way because I was browsing some discussion about varchar primary keys, which a lot of folks advise against for performance reasons. In this case, the key difference between using PRIMARY KEY vs UNIQUE KEY is that the former creates a clustered index and the later creates a non-clustered index. Because we will not be adding keys sequentially, this is less ideal for clustered indexes.
That said, I don't mind changing it. All of the other databases are currently defined with PRIMARY KEY, lookup should still be faster with the clustered index, and it's unclear how much of a difference it even makes.
